Original question: Are children allowed in Mormon temples?

Please don’t call them “Mormon” temples. The word “Mormon” does not appear anywhere on or in front of the sacred edifice. Engraved over the door is THE HOUSE OF THE LORD, from the Old Testament.

If that’s too religious for you to say, then there is a sign in front that says “Temple” and “The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints.”

Children do not routinely go to the temple. They do go in order to be sealed to their parents, but that is a once-in-a-lifetime event. If the child’s parents were sealed to each other before the child’s birth, then the child is automatically covered in that sealing and has no need to go redo that ordinance.

Young people can go to the temple as young as 11 years old to participate in proxy baptisms. In areas where there is a temple within reach, a young person will usually participate in that once or twice a year either with family or the local congregation going together.

Please keep in mind that the temple is not the local meetinghouse. The temple hosts no Sunday services, and there is no congregation there. Weekly services are held in the meetinghouse, which is open to the public. There families attend sacrament meeting together and children meet in the Primary Association.

Lives in Provo, UT (1966–present) · Author has 424 answers and 208.1K answer views · Dec 26 ·

Yes, under strict rules. When the parents are being sealed, their living children are taken care of during the endowment session, then the children are brought up to the sealing room to be sealed to their parents after they have been sealed to each other. In adoption cases, the parents are already sealed and the children can be sealed to the parents after the adoption is final. This can be any child under the age of 18. If parents get sealed to each other when children are older than 18, those children are required to be Temple worthy and received his/her own endowment to represent themselves in the sealing session.

There are other rules for youth for performing Baptisms for the dead. Young men and women who turn 12 during the calendar year can get a limited recommend for doing baptisms at the beginning of that year. They are allowed into the Baptistry area only

Do Mormons have a temple in their home?

We do not have temples in our homes, but we do consider our homes to be sacred places where families can grow in love and truth and knowledge.

Any structure in which these activities take place can be a “temple” of sorts. We even consider our bodies to be the temple of our spiritual selves, where the eternal essence of us can learn to love God and our neighbors— the two great commandments.

However, as has been said, our homes and our meeting houses are distinct from our temple buildings in purpose and function. But all three are sacred places.

What is a sealing room in a Mormon temple?

It’s a room where husbands and wives and whole families are sealed for eternity. Eternal marriages take place in sealing rooms. If a couple is converted to the Church after being married in a civil ceremony or in another church, they will be sealed in the temple after a year. If they have children born before they are married in the temple, those children will also be sealed to them. Children born to a couple after they are married in the temple are automatically sealed to them since they are born under the marriage covenant.

What’s inside Mormon temples?

When a new temple is built, you can attend the open house and see for yourself. All temples contain the same general features. https://www.lds.org/temples/open-houses?lang=eng

Near the front door is a desk where someone checks to see if you have a current temple recommend, which is your permission to enter. If you do not, you are politely declined entrance. Most temples have comfortable waiting rooms where you can stay if you are with a group who are allowed entrance.

There are offices for various temple workers. Some temples even contain apartments for the temple president and matron (wife).

How does a Mormon obtain a temple recommend? How long does it last? How does it work?

Background

First off, just a little background for those who may be less familiar with Mormonism and therefore may not understand exactly what you’re asking.

Members of The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints (the official name of the Mormon church) attend weekly church services on Sundays much like most mainstream Christians. While the format and tone of the Sunday services would seem somewhat different to anyone not familiar with them, they are basically analogous to those held in many other denominations. Specifically, the services are held in local chapels and are open to anyone who would like to attend regardless of whether they are members of the church or not, provided they are respectful during their visit.

These Mormon chapels can be found all over the place, in many neighborhoods where there are enough church members to justify them. In Utah and Idaho, there is a high enough density of Mormons that Mormon chapels are more common than McDonald’s and Starbucks franchises. What some people may not be aware of is that in addition to the common chapel buildings, Mormons have bigger, grander buildings known as temples. These temples are not for regular weekly Sunday services, but are reserved for specific ceremonies which can only be attended by members of the Mormon church in good standing. Because of this, in order to enter a Mormon temple, you need a pass card, known as a temple recommend.

Temple Recommends

A temple recommend is issued to members of the Mormon church to allow them to enter a temple and participate in ceremonies performed there. Before receiving a temple recommend, there are some prerequisites a member must follow:

  • They must have been a baptized member of the church for at least one year.
  • They must be an adult, generally at least 18 years old. (There are very specific exceptions where younger members can be granted one-time temporary recommends for the purpose of very specific ceremonies. For example, Mormons generally perform marriages in their temples, and if the couple have children, these children would generally be granted temporary recommends in order to participate in the ceremony. There are other examples, but the age rule generally holds.)
  • They must be an “active” member of the church. This generally means that they attend church services every week as far as they are able, and that they generally participate in church service as they are asked. (Most positions in the local churches are filled by lay people, who are asked to volunteer. Being asked to volunteer for a position is known a “filling a calling” or “being called.” Consistent unwillingness to fill callings when asked could make one deemed unworthy for a temple recommend.)
  • They must pay a full tithe. Faithful Mormons are required to pay 10% of their income to the church as tithing.
  • They must follow the commandments of the Mormon gospel. These include commandments that most Christians would be familiar with, but also include some peculiar to the Mormon church. For example, tobacco, alcohol, coffee, and tea are all forbidden by the church, and using any of these will generally make one unworthy to receive a temple recommend. Sex outside of marriage, masturbation, pornography and other things considered sinful by the Mormon church will also disqualify one from receiving a recommend.

In order to receive a temple recommend, a member has an interview with their bishop (the most local leadership position in the church, roughly equivalent to a pastor in a mainstream Christian church). In this interview, the bishop will assess both whether the member is prepared to attend temple ceremonies, and also whether the member meets the prerequisites listed above. They will generally specifically ask about many of the sins mentioned above, and may bring up anything they know about if the member tries to conceal it. Once this interview is passed, the member will have the same interview again with their stake president, which is a higher up local area leader who generally presides over several bishops.

Once the member has passed both of these interviews, they will receive a recommend which allows them to enter any Mormon temple in the world and participate in the ceremonies. Usually, the first time a member receives a recommend, they will be scheduled to attend their first ceremonies with another more experienced member (often a parent or other relative, when possible). Otherwise, more experienced members can attend on their own as they desire. When a member goes into the temple, there are church members who are assigned to work there (often older, retired members who do not have daily work commitments). Some of these temple workers will man the entrance lobby of the temple, and will check each incoming member for a current and valid temple recommend. Anyone entering without one will generally be turned away, though in extenuating circumstances, it is sometimes possible for the temple to contact a member’s bishop or stake president to confirm that the member does in fact have a valid recommend which they have simply forgotten or misplaced.

Temple recommends are generally good for two years, though they can be revoked by church leadership if the member’s behavior makes them unworthy to attend. Once a recommend expires, the member must go through the two stage interview process described above to receive a new one.

Do Mormons want non-Mormons to be allowed into their temples?

Original question: Do Mormons want non-Mormons to be allowed into their temples?

We are no longer called “Mormons.” We are Latter-day Saints.

We have 31,315 congregations in all 50 states and every province of Canada and 151 other countries. You, your family, and anyone else has a standing invitation to come at any time. We have services every Sunday, and there is always a little more room in the pews. I don’t know any member of the Church who does not wish more people would come.

I apologize if there is any doubt that people aren’t welcome. We should think about sending people out to invite others, and maybe putting up some welcome signs.

Separate from the meetinghouse is the sacred space we call the temple. Entry there is not for us to decide. It is the Lord’s house, and He decides the entry requirements. Anyone who enters is a guest there.

Latter-day Saints derive a lot of joy from working and serving in the temple. We always get a little excited when someone comes to the temple for the first time because we get to share that joy.

Even when the temple isn’t dedicated, we love to welcome our non-member friends, relatives, neighbors, and coworkers to the Temple open house. I recently helped host one. We welcomed over 335,000 people and I described it here on Quora as one of the happiest moments of my life.

We don’t worry about meetinghouses or temples getting overcrowded. They’ll always build more.

What do Mormons do in temples?

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothi

There are plenty of sources to go for this information. In my experience (I’ve seen many, many “debunking mormonism” type stuff) content not released directly by the church is almost always incorrect. Sadly, most of the time it is seemingly done intentionally. Lucky for us, the church has released many resources to tell people what the temple is and what’s done there.

I’ll provide a synopsis based on appropriate material that sums up what we do in temples and why they mean so much to us. Everything I say is “Church approved” (if I say something wrong, please correct me fellow members) but nothing I say speaks for the church in any official or unofficial way.

So what do we do in temples?

Well, we worship. We participate in ordinances for ourselves and for others. We reflect and meditate. We pray. We try to get close to God.

In the temple, we have a handful of ordinances that are performed by recommend-holding saints as young as 12. Acts in the temple are done either for oneself or on behalf of someone else. Mormons call this “proxy.” We believe that the dead are spiritually alive and capable of accepting the gospel.

We also believe that certain ordinances are essential for doing so. By serving for and in behalf of them by proxy, we grant them the opportunity to receive all promises available to the living. A faithful saint will hopefully perform each ordinance for themselves one time, and thereafter only do it in the service of the dead.

The ordinances are as follows:

  • Baptism and confirmation by proxy
  • Ordination into priesthood (for deceased males)
  • Endowment
    • Initiatory
    • Receiving the endowment (commonly called a “session”)
  • Sealing

I’ll explain each below as well as try to give the reader a picture of what it’s like without demeaning the sacred nature of it.

Proxy Baptism
Baptisms and confirmations for the dead are the only ordinances done by children, and others who have not been “endowed” (more on that later), with the exception of sealings for families converting to the gospel.

Temple baptisms are pretty straightforward. Participants are walked into a font that may look similar to the one above (the oxen represent Ephraim ushering the twelve tribes of Israel). A priesthood holder will then say a prayer including the name of the person for whom the baptism is performed and submerge the participant into the water completely. This is repeated many times, each person usually doing at least a handful of names before finishing.

Priesthood Confirmation

Confirmations simply involve a person sitting in a chair as priesthood holders lay their hands on their head and say a prayer for the deceased person receiving the priesthood. Pretty much just like the image below, but the chairs are more comfy, the surrounding is beautiful and those offering the prayer may have a chair or stool to sit on as well.

Temple Endowment

The endowment consists of two parts, the initiatory and the presentation (session). Initiatories are quick and consist of one being symbolically cleansed and anointed, after which they receive blessings related to their divine heritage. Most members doing initiatories for others will do anywhere from 5–15 at a time, depending on how much time is available.

The session portion of the endowment consists of a presentation of material, including “instruction on how all people can return to the presence of the Lord.”

[1]

Today, most temples use video for certain segments of the presentation. Only a few temples still use actors for the entire thing (“live session”). There are currently multiple videos of the presentation in rotation, all of them are produced in English and later translated into many languages.

(Sidenote: According to rumors I’ve heard, there is a possibility that the church is doing/planning on making films based around certain areas which would contain a more local-looking cast, local language, and stylistic form resembling local style. Just rumors, but pretty interesting stuff to me.)

Other pieces of the ceremony are conducted by temple workers, male and female. The endowment session ends with the participant in the “Celestial Room,” a lounge area beautified to represent heaven. Many people will spend some time there quietly before leaving. Most sessions will take about 2–3 hours total, depending on crowds, etc. and they are performed for only one person at a time.

Temple Sealings

Sealing is the “crowning blessing of the temple.”

[2]
To be “sealed” means that your family is bound together forever. This unity is the goal for our entire human race.

The sealing power is referred to in Matt 16:19: “And I will give thee the keys of the kingdom of heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt bind on earth shall be bound in heaven: and whatsoever thou shalt loose on earth shall be loosed in heaven.”

The ordinance itself is very brief and rather informal compared to other temple work. These occur in “sealing rooms” which have a bunch of chairs, an altar and usually mirrors on opposite walls (the mirrors are not part of the ceremony, but are often used to represent eternity as the mirrors reflect off each other infinitely). The officiator generally offers counsel and some spiritual thoughts, followed by a prayer of blessings promised to the couple (or family) who kneel at the altar while holding hands. The whole thing, including wait time, is usually about an hour or so.

Sealings are bonds that transcend mortal existence. As such, they are held with deep reverence. It’s also important to note that the sealing of families is not dependent on blood kinship. Many LDS families will adopt and seal children, thus creating an eternal family where all are united as one. As I said before, the unity of the human family is paramount to our belief system. We view the work done in the temple with solemnity and see it as a fulfillment of the final promise (as well as the final words) of the Old Testament.

“Behold, I will send you Elijah the prophet before the coming of the great and dreadful day of the Lord: And he shall turn the heart of the fathers to the children, and the heart of the children to their fathers, lest I come and smite the earth with a curse.” - Malachi 4:5–6

To learn more about the sealing power, check out my answer to another question What do Muslims and Christians think of Jews?

What happens if an LDS member wants to be Temple endowed but doesn't want to be sealed to their parents?

That would be a rarity to the point of 1:1,000,000. I've known of only one case even close to this hypothetical situation: Recent convert was abused by his father — did not want his parents sealed to each other, nor he to them. His terminal illness prevented his going to the Temple himself, so he does not fit the criterion in the the question.

However, as Brigham Young said, the grave is a mellowing place. It's not ours to condemn even those whose lives appear to be totally out of line with Gospel standards. We do the work when possible and let Father do the sorting out.

Who knows what the miracle of the Atonement of Jesus Christ can work?

BTW, we honored his wishes even after his death. We’ll let the Lord decide when, if ever, the ordinances are performed.

How do Mormon temples differ from regular churches?

Churches are for Sunday services and weekly events. Temples are closed Sundays.

Temples are used only for services that recommend holders can attend. They are either marriages, baptisms for the dead, or endowments.

How does the Mormon Temple keep track of adopted children?

How does the Mormon Temple keep track of adopted children? How does the LDS Temple keep track of adopted children?

Truth is, erase “adopted" from the equation. Temple work done is the same for adopted children as it is for biological children.

I don't think it is possible to be sealed to two sets of parents. Assuming the adoption is practically the world's most open adoption, and the adoptee knows all their bioligical relatives, it might be possible to do temple work for either family. I don't know.

The next issue is just that. Sometimes Adoptees don't know anything about their blood-relatives. Most of us are lucky if we know 1 parent, much less an entire family history's worth. It's much less trouble to just stick to doing adoptive family history where records and information are much easier to come by.

Anyway. How do they keep track?

Just like biological counterparts, when an adopted child is sealed to their family (whichever family they are living with, usually) that event is recorded. Baptisms, marriage, whatever happens, so on and so forth, etc. Those events are noted down. And with the invention of technology and computers, I image it's very easy to keep record of said events.

What happens during LDS (Mormon) temple ceremonies and why are church members not allowed to talk about it?

It depends on which ceremonies you mean. Most people who ask this are referring to Initiatory/Endowment ceremonies. Most everything that happens in those ceremonies is stuff you can read in Leviticus, it’s not difficult to find places online where spiteful ex-Mormons or vindictive anti-Mormons have put all of the clothing and ceremonies on display. So, they’re not really a secret in the age of the Internet.

What happens? We make promises to God. Husbands and wives make promises to one another. Men and women make promises about our responsibilities to one another. We are promised certain blessin

It depends on which ceremonies you mean. Most people who ask this are referring to Initiatory/Endowment ceremonies. Most everything that happens in those ceremonies is stuff you can read in Leviticus, it’s not difficult to find places online where spiteful ex-Mormons or vindictive anti-Mormons have put all of the clothing and ceremonies on display. So, they’re not really a secret in the age of the Internet.

What happens? We make promises to God. Husbands and wives make promises to one another. Men and women make promises about our responsibilities to one another. We are promised certain blessings from God predicated on faithfulness to certain promises. We’re given the garment that you may be aware that Latter-day Saints wear beneath their clothes. The clothes, the ceremony, and the room are all full of symbolism designed to encourage reflection on the nature of our existence and our relationship with God.

Why are we “not allowed” to talk about it? Think about how much Mormons are mocked and ridiculed for the simple, outward aspects of our faith (not drinking alcohol, not having premarital sex, paying tithing, going to 3 hours of church every Sunday). We hold the temple ceremonies to be sacred, holy, and special. We keep discussion about the temple ceremonies mostly within the walls of the temple in part because we have no desire to take what we hold sacred and precious and expose it to the mockery of which the world has no shortage.

The other half is that we believe the lord doesn’t wish people to be burdened with responsibilities they’re not ready for. We don’t baptize babies because we believe an understanding of the idea of right and wrong is necessary for baptism. We don’t saddle people with ministering responsibilities if they’re living their lives in a way that shuns the influence of the holy spirt; and we do that for their sake more than anyone else’s. In like manner, the temple ceremony involves serious promises with serious responsibilities and serious warnings from the Lord, and we would prefer that people be sufficiently spiritually prepared for the ordinances and covenants of the holy temple.

Much like what Paul said to the Corinthians:

“For the preaching of the cross is to them that perish foolishness; but unto us which are saved it is the power of God.”

Milk before meat. We want everyone to experience and know the blessings of the temple. But to truly appreciate them, and the responsibilities they provide, takes time and study and spiritual preparation.

Why do Mormons choose to have many children?

I’m a convert to Mormonism, having joined The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints at 16. I come from a line of liberal-minded Jews with small families and very well-educated kids. Family is central to Mormonism, and members are encouraged to bring as many kids into their families as they think is right for them. I ended up having six children and now have 15 (going on 17) grandkids and one great-grandchild.

My parents were pretty taken aback that I kept having children. My babies got smaller and smaller towards the end, and I determined I’d better not do another pregnancy. Birth control is not forbidden in the Church, and the decision of how many kids to have and when is up to us to figure out as husband and wife while counseling with the Lord.

We are having a blast. Not only was our household lively and fun, but having a large family is a huge support for everyone. I wouldn’t mind if there were more of us. We couldn’t afford expensive advanced education for our children, but those who desired to obtained advanced degrees from good schools. We travelled widely and did have fun, enriching experiences all over the world.

On the opposite side of the spectrum, my parents had three children. My sister died at age 44, and my parents have been gone 20 years. Only my brother and I are left, and it’s a whole different story. Would that there were more of us.

Can children of non-Latter Day Saints (LDS) parents go through the Mormon Temple Endowment ceremony without parental permission?

The endowment ceremony in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints is something that is offered in adulthood, not to children. These days the earliest it is generally offered is to 18 year old's preparing for mission or marriage (if a young woman is getting married with parent permission prior to 18 in a temple, she can get a temple recommend and receive her endowment). Point being, as it is essentially an ordinance of adulthood, there’s no permission needed from parents. If you want to get it, you talk with your bishop and he will help you out. While we typically don’t recommend hiding

The endowment ceremony in the Church of Jesus Christ of Latter Day Saints is something that is offered in adulthood, not to children. These days the earliest it is generally offered is to 18 year old's preparing for mission or marriage (if a young woman is getting married with parent permission prior to 18 in a temple, she can get a temple recommend and receive her endowment). Point being, as it is essentially an ordinance of adulthood, there’s no permission needed from parents. If you want to get it, you talk with your bishop and he will help you out. While we typically don’t recommend hiding things from family, there’s no reason to even discuss your choice here if you know they will be bothered by it.

What are Mormon temple celebrations?

The temple in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the pinnacle of our worship of Jesus Christ. In the temple, we make covenants with God that we will follow His Son Jesus Christ and commit our all to Him, and in return, God promises that we will receive the blessings of exaltation after the Second Coming of Christ.

Sounds like a lot? It is. Making promises with God is no small matter. And the only place you can do that is in the temple. That’s why we celebrate: another House of the Lord for us to enter and sample what heaven will be like. Another place where we can experience par

The temple in The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints is the pinnacle of our worship of Jesus Christ. In the temple, we make covenants with God that we will follow His Son Jesus Christ and commit our all to Him, and in return, God promises that we will receive the blessings of exaltation after the Second Coming of Christ.

Sounds like a lot? It is. Making promises with God is no small matter. And the only place you can do that is in the temple. That’s why we celebrate: another House of the Lord for us to enter and sample what heaven will be like. Another place where we can experience part of what it will be like to be in God’s presence.

So we celebrate. We gather all the saints in the area where the temple is being constructed. We perform cultural dances and sing songs that remind us of the people who live in the area and how they now have local access to the House of the Lord. We praise the builders and those who will work and volunteer inside the temple. Finally, we dedicate the temple to the Lord, offering it to Him as a house where we can enter and be taught.

This shouldn’t be seen as weird. Just take a look at what goes on in your community all the time. People hold ribbon cuttings for new businesses and hospitals. We have grand openings for car dealerships and parties for new restaurants. It’s no strange thing to celebrate the opening of a new building that will benefit the residents of that area.

When a new literal house of God is finally ready for His people to enter, that they can learn how they can receive all the blessings He wants them to obtain in this life and the next, it rightfully should be the most important grand opening celebration of any building on Earth because of what it means for everyone: God lives; He loves all His children; He speaks to each of us individually; He sent His Son Jesus Christ to prepare us to return to God and become like Him; and the temple is where those truths are taught best.

Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

Original question: Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

We are not called “Mormons” anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

We have two different kinds of houses of worship. One is the temple. The other is the meetinghouse. They are not the same. They are not interchangeable.

We sometimes call the temple the house of the Lord. That is what is engraved over the door. The temple is a holy place reserved for sacred ordinances performed by those who have prepared themselves spiritually. Some of the faithful make great sacrifices to be able to travel the temple once or twice in their live

Original question: Do Mormons have two different names for their temples?

We are not called “Mormons” anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

We have two different kinds of houses of worship. One is the temple. The other is the meetinghouse. They are not the same. They are not interchangeable.

We sometimes call the temple the house of the Lord. That is what is engraved over the door. The temple is a holy place reserved for sacred ordinances performed by those who have prepared themselves spiritually. Some of the faithful make great sacrifices to be able to travel the temple once or twice in their lives.

This is the Bern Switzerland Temple. Inside the temple we wear white. This is not a meetinghouse.

We usually refer to the meetinghouse as the church, or sometimes the chapel. There are thousands of meetinghouses in over 100 countries, purposely built close to where people live. They are multipurpose structures for worship and other activities. In the meetinghouse we prepare ourselves to go to the temple. There is a new meetinghouse built on average every week. You are welcome to any of our meetinghouses any time you like.

This meetinghouse in Hermiston, Oregon is typical of the the newer meetinghouses. It’s not fancy, but it’s easily recognizable. It is not a temple.

We also pray in our homes.

What is the Mormon temple made of?

Original question: What is the Mormon temple made of?

Thank you for this question, If you’re talking about the iconic Salt Lake Temple, then it’s made of solid granite. The walls are 9 feet thick at the base. It was built between 1853 and 1893, and is currently undergoing a five-year renovation and seismic retrofit. Church President Brigham Young (1801–1877) told architect Truman O. Angell (1810–1887) he wanted it to last until the end of the Millennium.

When the renovation is complete, you will be invited to the open house prior to the rededication.

If you’re asking about one of the other temple

Original question: What is the Mormon temple made of?

Thank you for this question, If you’re talking about the iconic Salt Lake Temple, then it’s made of solid granite. The walls are 9 feet thick at the base. It was built between 1853 and 1893, and is currently undergoing a five-year renovation and seismic retrofit. Church President Brigham Young (1801–1877) told architect Truman O. Angell (1810–1887) he wanted it to last until the end of the Millennium.

When the renovation is complete, you will be invited to the open house prior to the rededication.

If you’re asking about one of the other temples, it could be sandstone, limestone, or reinforced steel. They are not built to the local or commercial standard like the usual cheap-o-rama buildings of Protestant denominations, but a much higher standard. Of course that costs more, and that’s fine because building a temple is an act of devotion to God.

By the way, it’s not called the “Mormon” temple anymore. We are Latter-day Saints.

If you are not ready to make these covenants - and you do not believe that we are God's authorized representatives in such matters - you have no reason to go to the temple. The Church of Jesus Christ of Latter-day Saints welcomes you to attend its meetinghouses throughout the world and join in our Sunday worship. All are welcome.

What we do in the temple is not what we do in our normal Sunday worship services. We go to the temple to make and renew special covenants with God.
